Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Smartphone Enabled Social and Physical Compass System (SENSCOPS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Smartphones equipped with powerful embedded sensors (e.g. accelerometers, GPS, microphones, etc.) can be used to monitor multiple dimensions of human behaviors including physical, mental, and social behaviors of wellbeing. In particular, such enhanced capabilities in mobile devices enable people to better manage their health. Existing mobile health applications mostly rely on manual data entry which may not be sufficient for certain population e.g. seniors and students with emotional behavioral disorders (EBD). This project aims to build a multimodal sensing system which provides continuous and efficient monitoring of users? activities using mobile phones and wearable sensors. Our system analyzes and correlates different sensor streams to infer certain behaviors as well as possible environmental factors that may trigger such behaviors. Furthermore, our system provides non-intrusive peer assisted localization technique that allows caregivers to track the whereabouts of monitored users. We also develop efficient schemes to infer higher layer information e.g. activity levels of monitored individuals; social relationships among monitored users. Additionally, the communities extracted from a mobile phone enabled social network in our system not only enable mobile healthcare systems but can also be exploited for securing certain components of the system (e.g., coping with clone attacks). Our system allows users to be monitored for their mental, cognitive, and physical well-being and can potentially reduce the cost for special need education as a result of increasing the productivity of teachers and caregivers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits:

*we have deisgned a critical segment based real-time e-signature scheme for securing  mobile transactions. our scheme can achieve high accuracy.

* we have designed a smartphone based user verification scheme leveraging gait recognition for mobile healthcare systems. We have demonstrated that our scheme is efficient and can achieve high accuray.

* we have designed and evaluated a privacy aware disease treatment & complication prediction system that allows users to submit health related queries. Our results indicate that our designed scheme achieves good performance.

* we have designed and evalauted an incentive scheme which allows healthcare service providers to solicit high quality crowdsourcing data for disease progression and survival rate prediction. Our evaluation results show that our scheme is useful in encouraging hospitals to share truthful data.

* we have designed an efficient deep-learning based mobile object recognition scheme which enables low cost robots to infer objects they see in a home. We have demonstrated that our scheme can be implemented in smartphones and other resource constrained devices.

* we have designed a secure & efficient hierarchical based image retreival system which allows users to find matching images quickly. Our evaluation results show that our scheme performs better than existing schemes.

Broader Impacts:

* We have released a few Android applications and 2 version of Kinect games for autistic teenagers and children. One version of the Kinect games has been used in autism respite events for the past 2 years. Another event will take place on April 8th, 2017. Released applications can be accessed from this URL:  http://carina.cse.lehigh.edu/graceland

* We have produced several computer scientists and engineers which were hired by high tech companies such as Microsoft, Google, Samsung Research, Huawei, and startup companies. Two of the students graduated with PhDs, one graduated with MS degree and a few graduated with bachelor degrees.

*We have published a few papers at top conference venues: INFOCOM 2017 paper, AsiaCCS 2016, CNS 2015, ICCV 2015, MMSys 2015, WACV 2015, SECON 2013 and two journal papers - one at IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing and another at International Journal of Multimedia Data Engineering and Management 

* We have incorporated some of our research results into existing undergraduate/graduate courses we offer e.g. Mobile Conmputing.
